text: <@UE6EFEPTQ> Yeah, should have posted to <#C5T9GPWFL|general> but whatevs. I checked out Term Rewriting And All That from my library today. So far it’s concerned with (equational, i.e. first order) term rewriting as computation: normal forms, confluence, termination. Concepts that seemed important if I wanted to write optimizations for a compiler, say, or to prove things about programs written in a term rewriting system. It wasn’t clear to me that I needed to know much while I prototype and build simple applications.
<@UCUSW7WVD> yeah, it would make SQL much, much more pleasant to use. Also reminds me of Datomic’s pull api

<https://youtu.be/if72CFsF_SY> surprised that dan ingalls’ work gets very little play here—some interesting stuff in this talk, including structural editing via drag and drop (with text, so a possible evolution of the block paradigm)

text: it’s definitely super similar to datomic pull—which, given the rise of graphql, seems to be an emerging meme
Thanks for sharing, this is super useful!
dunno if anyone’s been following mark nadal/gun js but his work is a tour de force for decentralized computing, clever algorithms, and low code size: <https://youtu.be/5fCPRY-9hkc>

text: I thought that Lively Web was an old and abandoned project, but that is not true at all. Lots of interesting-looking stuff at <http://lively-next.org>.

attachments.title: lively.next
attachments.text: lively.next is a personal programming kit. It emphasizes liveness, directness and interactivity.

text: Have to say the SQL one looks better. :smile:
But of course Onex has Other Powers that SQL doesn't..
Onex is a distributed structure rewrite language, not a query language.
Plus I agree with Mr Meander that our approaches feel like you're looking at the actual data
One of the croquet team member is Yoshiki Ohshima, who was at HARC.
Also found this article very helpful. It makes me understand CRDT and look at Causal Tree which I found very interesting to implement offline first decentralised tools.
my god—they’ve finally found a visual designer!
anyone who thinks statecharts are interesting should check out microstates.js: <https://youtu.be/zWEg4-bGot0>
